node.title: CP maximum allowable slip rate
node.bodyText:
Hello, I am running a compression test on a cylindre with 300 grains, a mesh with 111,000 DoF, a height of 72 mm. I want to reach 2% strain I have set the forced displacement at 10^-5 * t and a time step to reach a maximum of 72 (starting at 1 with the help of timestepper) but I keep getting warnings of the form of : 'Maximum allowed slip increment exceeded'. I've set the slip increment to 10. Is there a way to calibrate this slip increment value to optimize the time step and loading rate and still not have to wait forever to reach at least 1% strain. Thanks !!
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Mesh]
  [file]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = n300-id1.msh
  []
  [sidesets]
    type = SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator
    input =file
    normals = '0 0 -1
                0 0 1'
    fixed_normal = true
    new_boundary = 'bottom top'
  []
[]


[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic/all]
  strain = FINITE
  add_variables = true
  save_in = 'resid_x resid_y resid_z'
[]

[BCs]
  [symmy]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0
  []
  [symmx]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0
  []
  [symmz]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0
  []
  [tdisp]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = top
    function = '-1e-5*t'
  []
[]

[UserObjects]
  [prop_read]
    type = PropertyReadFile
    prop_file_name = 'input_euler.txt'
    nprop =4
    ngrain = 300
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorCP
    C_ijkl = '48.7e3 11.9e3 11.9e3 48.7e3 11.9e3 48.7e3 13.1e3 13.1e3 13.1e3'
    fill_method = symmetric9
    read_prop_user_object = prop_read
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress
    crystal_plasticity_models = 'trial_xtalpl'
    tan_mod_type = exact
    maximum_substep_iteration = 10
  []
  [trial_xtalpl]
    type = CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate
    number_slip_systems = 12
    slip_sys_file_name = input_slip_sys.txt
    ao = 2e-3
    gss_a = 2
    gss_initial = 10
    h = 100
    r = 1.4
    xm = 0.1
    t_sat = 100.
    resistance_tol = 1.0
    print_state_variable_convergence_error_messages = true
    slip_increment_tolerance = 10
  []
[]


[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_type -ksp_gmres_restart'
  petsc_options_value = ' lu       gmres     200'
  solve_type = NEWTON
  automatic_scaling = true
  line_search = 'none'
  dtmin = 5e-12
  dtmax = 72
  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 1 # Initial time step.  In this simulation it changes.
        cutback_factor = 0.25
     growth_factor = 1.2
     optimal_iterations = 20
  [../]
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_max_its = 20
  end_time = 6e5 
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  interval = 70
[]

Also the dt stopped increasing at 16.5618 is there a way to have better convergence and increase time step.

Hello
Do you mean the mesh has 110,000 cells? The number of dofs is tied to the number of variables. what does the simulation summary say for the number of DOFs?
Above 100k dofs it may be time to look at improving the preconditioning.

Mesh:
  Parallel Type:           replicated
  Mesh Dimension:          3
  Spatial Dimension:       3
  Nodes:
    Total:                 37330
    Local:                 1438
    Min/Max/Avg:           1005/1520/1244
  Elems:
    Total:                 90191
    Local:                 3093
    Min/Max/Avg:           2919/3096/3006
  Num Subdomains:          300
  Num Partitions:          30
  Partitioner:             metis

Nonlinear System:
  Num DOFs:                111990
  Num Local DOFs:          4314
  Variables:               { "disp_x" "disp_y" "disp_z" }
  Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE"
  Approximation Orders:    "FIRST"

I have 111.9k DoF which is relatively small for a cp computation. What do you mean by improving the preconditioning

Using a different solver package for LU or finding a different method
I wonder if you are using too many processors at this point. 4k dofs per processor is not a lot. Can you try using half as many processors to see if the performance improves?
Tried using mumps and 10 processors but it still takes too long.. 25min for 0.0025% strain

You've identified the correct parameter to adjust for the slip tolerance, and here's the context in case that helps you decide how much more you want to increase that value:

  
    
      moose/modules/solid_mechanics/src/materials/crystal_plasticity/CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate.C
    
    
         Line 99
      in
      ad167a6
    
  
  
    

        
          
           if (std::abs(_slip_increment[_qp][i]) * _substep_dt > _slip_incr_tol) 
        
    
  


I usually balance between the slip increment tolerance, slip_increment_tolerance, (and when appropriate the state variable tolerance, stol, and the slip resistance tolerance, resistance_tol) and the maximum_substep_iteration, but I don't have a good optimization procedure. I have found that keep the maximum_substep_iteration at or below 5 seems to help; after more than 5 substeps the simulations seem to slow down noticeably.
Ok thank you. Keeping maximum_substep_iteration below 5 has helped the most.

You may also like to look into the NEML2 submodule (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/solid_mechanics/NEML2.html), which does have full derivatives of the model terms through libTorch. @hugary1995 can better describe the capabilities of NEML2 than I can

node.title: Should Moose check block-restriction in FEProblemBase::duplicateVariableCheck

node.bodyText:
Hello
If you want the message to be more verbose and give more information (such as the block restriction) then that would work for us. Already it says "different type" but it would help the user to say which types are involved
However we can't really allow the check to let two "identical" variables be added without some serious checking. There are many variable parameters, we would have to check them all, not just the block restriction.
Guillaume
I'll try to prepare an PR.

node.title: Error while run tests after updates
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
After updating conda moose environment and get the latest updates for moose, I got the following error message while trying to run_test.
:241: RuntimeWarning: compile time version 3.10 of module 'hit' does not match runtime version 3.11
Segmentation fault: 11
Any help on having the issue solved will be much appreciated.

Hello
The hit warning could be red herring
Let's run a single input for example in test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion and see if the error can be isolated there

I run the test as
../../../moose_test-opt -i simple_diffusion.i
and got the following error
Illegal instruction: 4
BTW, I'm running MacOS Sonoma version14.6.1 (23G93).

ugh. This does not give us much
Is this a fresh install? If not then I would git clean -xfD the repo (in moose/) then try again
If so, then we ll need to run a debugger and hope we get better information
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html

I wonder if this could be folks performing an update with Conda, getting the OpenMPI compilers by accident, and running MOOSE which has some stale libs built with MPICH.
I think what @GiudGiud mentioned is the right approach. Clean the build, and build anew. But let's also make sure that you are using the 'better' stack. Can you perform the following and report back:
conda activate moose
condo list | grep moose

I did rebuild after clean -xdf, even reinstalled moose and conda. The issue now changed to all tests failed and when ran the simple_diffusion.i test, got the same error. Here is what returned after running 'conda list | grep moose':
moose-dev                 2024.07.27                mpich    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh             2024.07.27              mpich_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh-vtk         9.3.0                   mpich_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-mpi                 2024.07.10                mpich    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-peacock             2024.07.10              mpich_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-petsc               3.20.3                  mpich_1    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-tools               2024.07.19      py311h09a46a1_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-wasp                2024.05.08              build_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public

I think this qualifies for running the diagnostic script in its more "troubleshooting" fashion. To see if this machine is having other more serious issues, or if this is an environment issue.
cd ~/projects/moose/scripts
export METHOD=opt METHODS=opt MOOSE_JOBS=6
./diagnostics.sh --full-build
Diagnostics will attempt to do everything in a clean environment, all in a temp directory, from scratch. So it may take a while. But it will help tell us if building and running moose is even possible on this machine.
Edit:
I am running this on my own, as it's been a while... and I seem to hit a snag when building libMesh. Might happen to you. Working on a fix.
Edit:
If you are running into an issue with the above (failing to build libMesh) try modifying the moose/scripts/diagnostics.sh script like so:
at line (241) 
  
    
      moose/scripts/diagnostics.sh
    
    
         Line 241
      in
      e0de659
    
  
  
    

        
          
           MOOSE_PACKAGES="${MPI_PACKAGES} packaging pyaml jinja2 python" 
        
    
  


-MOOSE_PACKAGES="${MPI_PACKAGES} packaging pyaml jinja2 python"
+MOOSE_PACKAGES="${MPI_PACKAGES} zlib packaging pyaml jinja2 python"
(add zlib to the list)

I can run the diagnostics without any changes to the file. But it completed with 7 tests failed, all of which are for the web_server_control:
controls/web_server_control.get_postprocessor ................................................. FAILED (CRASH)
controls/web_server_control.connect_port ...................................................... FAILED (CRASH)
controls/web_server_control.errors/set_controllable_no_exist ................. FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)
controls/web_server_control.errors/postprocessor_no_exist .................... FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)
controls/web_server_control.errors/set_controllable_unregistered_type ........ FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)
controls/web_server_control.errors/set_controllable_bad_convert_json ......... FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)
controls/web_server_control.errors/set_controllable_vector_non_array ......... FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)

Yeah that's normal (the web server tests failing).
Okay, looks like this means there is going to be something in your environment causing the failures.
We will need to take a closer look at the difference between these two environments:
Open a new terminal and:
conda activate moose
env | sort > ~/bad_env
And this environment
/usr/bin/env -i bash --norc --noprofile
# do the bits to manually source the conda environment. Just a guess if you installed
# Miniforge as described on our wiki to the letter:
export PATH=~/miniforge/bin:$PATH
source activate ~/miniforge/envs/moose
env | sort > ~/good_env
And then compare the two:
sdiff ~/good_env ~/bad_env
There is no miniforge directory on my computer, and only miniconda3.

In your case then:
/usr/bin/env -i bash --norc --noprofile
export PATH=~/miniconda3/bin:$PATH
source activate ~/miniconda3/envs/moose
env | sort > ~/good_env
This is the comparison result:

I ran through the same issue when I updated my moose and conda. Initially, I was getting the segmentation fault. Then I tried updating running ./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh, ./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh and update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh which led me to this error while running ./run_tests: Logfile.txt. Seems like libMesh could not locate the VTK.
@hchen139 Could you find any solution?

@MinMorsh, your issue not related to Illegal instruction: 4. Please begin a new discussion (if you already have, I apologize... I am simply addressing discussions as I receive them in my email). Your issue is a simple one as well, which I cannot answer here (cannot mark my post as answering this thread as it does not pertain to the original post).

I think I have a possible explanation for this, with a fix in libMesh/libmesh#3940
I'll post a further update once the fix is downstream and we have conda modules with it ready for testing.

The fix is now in all branches of moose. If you update with
conda install moose-dev=2024.08.30 mpich

then:

save all your work in moose
go to moose/
git clean -Xfd
then recompile with make
you should get working binaries
Problem solved! Much appreciated for the help to the team.

node.title: MOOSE install: successful build, but got failed tests
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
Hi MOOSE community,
I have followed the tutorial to install MOOSE on MacOS. I seem to have built MOOSE using make, but when I run the tests, it shows a lot of failed tests (50) and none of them pass.
Could anyone in the community please help with this issue? Some of the error outputs are listed below.

Hello
Could you please go in test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion and run that test (using the executable in moose/test) and report the full log?
Thanks
Guillaume

Thanks for the reply. I use the exec in the simple_diffusion case file by
../../../moose_test-opt -i simple_diffusion.i

and returns
zsh: illegal hardware instruction

Am I using the correct command for the exec or does it indicate a problem? Thanks.

Ok this is a current failure we are investigating
The only solution we have for now is to revert to the moose-dev package of mid July
So something like
Conda install moose-dev=2024.07.17
Use conda search moose-dev to get the exact numbers

I tried uninstall and use the previous version as
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.07.15 mpich

However, the tests still report similar (a lot) errors related to the 'misc/check_error'

Did it build well the second time?
What does it do in the simple_diffusion folder again?

An error occurs when I make again.
In file included from /Users/me/projects/moose/framework/build/unity_src/systems_Unity.C:10:

  ^

                                                    ^

make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....

For the simple diffusion test, I do not find the exec 'moose_test-opt' in moose/test file this time.
zsh: no such file or directory: ../../../moose_test-opt

The executable does not build. Probably because moose is relying on libmesh features that are only present in newer versions of the package.
So we are toast with current moose.
You ll need to check out a version of moose from mid July as well. That one will build with libmesh from mid July
Linking with #28340 to keep track.

It's finally working by installing the version of 07.19. Almost all tests passed and the simple diffusion case also worked well.
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.07.19 mpich 

Also, be reminded to clean the build before 'make'
cd moose
git clean -xfd; git submodule foreach --recursive git clean -xfd

Thank you for your time, Guillaume @GiudGiud  and @milljm.
Dang... I mean, I am glade its working, but this whole "install an older package" thing is certainly not the solution.
We're identifying the issue: #28484

I think I've got a problem related to this having tried to do a conda and moose update.
I proceeded as normal and got an error while running make and failure running tests.
I had a look on the forum and found this issue, related threads and what looks like the recent change to the "new users - staying up-to-date" advice (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/new_users.html). So I have tried to apply the fixes here.
Now I seem to have removed moose with
conda env remove -n moose
but can't reinstall either the 2024.08.26 or 2024.07.19 versions using the commands:
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.08.26 mpich
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.07.19 mpich
I'm trying to do this from "base" in conda.  I get these messages and then the installation just hangs. I left it overnight for 12+ hours and nothing happened.  It's just sat there waiting to collect a package.
(base) timodel01@M0239:~$ conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.08.26 mpich
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done
Solving environment: unsuccessful attempt using repodata from current_repodata.json, retrying with next repodata source.
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): /
How can I expedite the package delivery?

hello
you have to update conda first : conda update conda
Older versions of conda are insanely slow with many packages. The new ones are fine. This is why we switched to mamba and then back to conda

Great - thanks I'm trying this.  It seems to be working.
Is the current recommendation to update moose with the 2024.08.26 or 2024.07.19 version?

And I get this warning on the conda update:

==> WARNING: A newer version of conda exists. <==
current version: 23.5.2
latest version: 24.7.1
Please update conda by running
$ conda update -n base -c conda-forge conda

Or to minimize the number of packages updated during conda update use
 conda install conda=24.7.1


Is it recommended or necessary to do either of these?

updating conda further wont hurt

Is the current recommendation to update moose with the 2024.08.26 or 2024.07.19 version?

some machines are affected by an "illegal instruction" error with the latest version. If your machine is brand new you can try the latest.
Rolling back both moose-libmesh and your local version of moose to mid-July will work for older and newer machines

I tried the conda update, but it just repeats the same warning that a newer version exists.  It doesn't seem to update with the newer vesion.
As I'm using an older machine with existing installations I've tried again with the July version:

conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.07.19 mpich

It's now got a step further.  The first attempt at collecting package metadata is "done".  But then solving environment is unsucessful with the repodata.  However the second collecting of repodata now worked but it's hung on solving environment for this.
Prompted by your comment above on conda being slow, and from a bit of googling, I see this is not unusual.  To get this to work quicker, could I retry with mamba, or is there a way I can force conda to update to version 24.7.1?

so this does not work?
 conda install conda=24.7.1
You can try with mamba if you would like
it's just conda install mamba then open a new tab then mamba install ...
note that sometimes it s easier to remove the miniconda/miniforge directory and re-download everything from this page
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
It mostly removes any long dependency solve

There is sometimes not an update path forward available for your installation of Conda. I have found this to be the case in the most recent upgrade process (from 23 to 24).
The solution in this case is to completely delete your current installation of Conda and install anew:
rm -rf ~/miniforge

# Linux
# curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-Linux-x86_64.sh

# Intel Mac
#curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-MacOSX-x86_64.sh

# Apple Si Mac
# curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-MacOSX-arm64.sh

bash Miniforge3-the-thing-you-downloaded-above -b -p ~/miniforge
exit
And then re-open your terminal window(s). No need to run conda init routines as those functions are already present in your shell profile.
At this point, it doesn't hurt to perform an update in the base environment:
conda activate base
conda update --all --yes
Finally, you should be able to install (quickly) the desired Conda packages.
We're still working on getting the "Illegal Instruction" issue solved...

That's fixed it!  New conda installation.  Moose reinstalled using latest August version with no errors and test passed.  My application updated and now running a model.  (Sort of - it isn't coverging, but fixing that is something I can try to sort out myself.)
Thank you so much!

node.title: Assigning different material properties to gauss point
node.bodyText:
Hi @GiudGiud
I am working on a project that requires varying the material properties for different gauss points.
For instance 2D plate will have Gauss points, and I want to assign different materials to each Gauss point in order to increase x
For instance,
[Materials]
[compute_stress1]
type = ComputeNeoHookeanStress
lambda = 40.0
mu = 67.0
x = 0.1, all y
[]
[compute_stress2]
type = ComputeNeoHookeanStress
lambda = 400.0
mu = 670.0
x =0.2, all y
[]
[compute_stress3]
type = ComputeNeoHookeanStress
lambda = 4000.0
mu = 6700.0
x = 0.3, all y
[]
[compute_strain]
type = ComputeLagrangianStrain
[]
[]

and so on

I am struggling with that as I don't know the location of gauss points coordinate
Or
  **if (_large_kinematics)
  {
      if ( _q_point[_qp](1) = 0.1;) {
        RankTwoTensor Cinv = (2 * _E[_qp] + RankTwoTensor::Identity()).inverse();
        _S[_qp] = 100* (_lambda[_qp] * log(_F[_qp].det()) - _mu[_qp]) * Cinv +
              _mu[_qp] * RankTwoTensor::Identity();
        _C[_qp] =100*(
            -2 * (_lambda[_qp] * log(_F[_qp].det()) - _mu[_qp]) * Cinv.times<i_, k_, l_, j_>(Cinv) +
            _lambda[_qp] * Cinv.times<i_, j_, k_, l_>(Cinv));
    }  
      if ( _q_point[_qp](1) = 0.2;) {
        RankTwoTensor Cinv = (2 * _E[_qp] + RankTwoTensor::Identity()).inverse();
        _S[_qp] = 1000* (_lambda[_qp] * log(_F[_qp].det()) - _mu[_qp]) * Cinv +
              _mu[_qp] * RankTwoTensor::Identity();
        _C[_qp] =1000*(
            -2 * (_lambda[_qp] * log(_F[_qp].det()) - _mu[_qp]) * Cinv.times<i_, k_, l_, j_>(Cinv) +
            _lambda[_qp] * Cinv.times<i_, j_, k_, l_>(Cinv));
    }  
      if ( _q_point[_qp](1) = 0.3;){
        RankTwoTensor Cinv = (2 * _E[_qp] + RankTwoTensor::Identity()).inverse();
        _S[_qp] = 10000* (_lambda[_qp] * log(_F[_qp].det()) - _mu[_qp]) * Cinv +
              _mu[_qp] * RankTwoTensor::Identity();
        _C[_qp] =10000*(
            -2 * (_lambda[_qp] * log(_F[_qp].det()) - _mu[_qp]) * Cinv.times<i_, k_, l_, j_>(Cinv) +
            _lambda[_qp] * Cinv.times<i_, j_, k_, l_>(Cinv));
    }  
  }**

Hello
We dont have very objects to output the quadrature points.
I think the cleanest might be to create a QuadraturePointsPositions object and get the JSON output from there.
I ll get started on this right now
#28565 has a new Positions object that will output the quadrature points to JSON

Hi @GiudGiud
I tried as per that discussion, but I am getting an error
*** ERROR ***
A 'QuadraturePointsPositions' is not a registered object.
If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically loaded library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.�[39m
#Tensor Mechanics tutorial: the basics
#Step 1, part 1

[GlobalParams]

did you pull that branch and built it?
You can either do that or add the source and header to your local installation then rebuild
for clarification, this object is not in the moose source code yet, I just made it this afternoon. So you have to either use my branch or add it to your code

Hi @GiudGiud
I add it to my local moose app,
did you recompile?
yes

umm.
then I guess:

save all your work, include this new object, with git commit
go in the top folder of your app
git clean -Xfd
recompile with make -j 6
try again

Hi @GiudGiud
I tried but getting the same error

you can try to re-register the object by changing the registerMooseObject call in QuadraturePointsPositions.C
when you do, check that the object is being properly recompiled

no this wont work
if ( _q_point[_qp](https://github.com/idaholab/moose/discussions/1) = 0.052831216351296784;) {

this sets (single = instead of two ==) the value of the q point
AND
the quadrature point will never be exactly equal to  0.052831216351296784, you need a tolerance.
So instead
if (MooseUtils::absoluteFuzzyEqual(_q_point[_qp](1), 0.052831216351296784))

this used a 1e-12 tolerance iirc, enough here

node.title: How to set target value in eigensolver?
node.bodyText:
Is there an interface in Moose to set the target value in eigen solver?
I know it is possible in SLEPc, I couldn't figure out how to set it in Moose.

Hello
Do you mean setting a target value then adjusting parameters to make the solution be this target value?
Or do you mean selecting an eigenmode by selecting a known eigenvalue?

I would look at this example modules/solid_mechanics/test/tests/modal_analysis/modal.i.
We can pass any petsc/slepc options using the interface
petsc_options_iname = '-st_type -eps_target -st_pc_type -st_pc_factor_mat_solver_type'
petsc_options_value = 'sinvert 0 lu mumps'
Thank you for the info. I didn't realize the solution is right there.

node.title: New Material Definition

node.bodyText:
hello
The headers seem to be nested under src/materials. We expect them to be under include/materials here
That's probably not the problem.
Did the application recompile correctly? Can you use the other objects you created?
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud
It compiled correctly and I am getting the same error "Not a registered object".
I have tried to put in include/materials but the same error persists.
A few months back, I defined in the same way src/materials and it was working correctly. I re-installed the moose as I was some other issues with login-id
Now after re-installment I am facing this issue

ok so:

save all your work with git commit
git clean -Xfd in the root directory of the app
recompile

if it still doesnt work, same but git cleaning moose as well before recompiling

Hi @GiudGiud
It worked
Thank you so much for the help

node.title: Applying gradient after time interval
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am trying to implement a spatial gradient (DD_Scaling) after a time interval. Part of the code looks like this:
"[./Scaling_DD]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'DD_Scaling'
    material_property_names = 'DD_bl hbl1'
    expression =  (hbl1*DD_bl )'
    outputs = exodus
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./density]
    type = GenericFunctionMaterial
    material_property_names = 'DD_Scaling'
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = 'if(t<150,0,DD_Scaling)'
    #outputs = exodus
  [../]"

However, GenericFunctionMaterial does not allow using a derivativeparsedmaterial into it. So what is the way to use a spatial gradient after a time interval?
I appreciate your response. Thanks.

Hello
I think a parsedMaterial will do well for defining this 'if' condition, using the expression parameter

@GiudGiud changed the code to
[./Scaling_DD]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'DD_Scaling'
    material_property_names = 'DD_bl hbl1'
    expression =  (hbl1*DD_bl )'
    outputs = exodus
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
[./density]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'density'
    material_property_names = 'DD_Scaling'
    expression = 'if(t<150,0,DD_Scaling)'
    #outputs = exodus
  [../]

However, now showing error:
*** ERROR ***
Invalid function
if(t<150,0,DD_Scaling)
DD_Scaling
in ParsedMaterialHelper.
Syntax error: Unknown identifier

Any solution for that?
Thanks.

how old is your version of moose?
I think t is not recognized by the ParsedMaterial
You ll need to define t as a function, with a ParsedFunction with use_xyzt set to true for example
@GiudGiud I did not update MOOSE recently. good news is solved the issue. We need ParsedFunction with FunctionAux. appreciate, cheers.

node.title: Code developed to Integrate a Gradient on a Surface
node.bodyText:
I have modified some code to determine the value of the surface integral pictured. The values that are being calculated from the code as developed are not in total agreement with the reference value. Would you be as so kind to review what I have modified and point out the potential errors that I have that may be causing my errors?
SideDiffusiveFluxDotNormIntegralDotComp_crab_C.txt
SideDiffusiveFluxDotNormIntegralDotComp_crab_h.txt

Hello
There's a lot in this expression. is u_tau the tangeantial component to a vector field, tangeant to the surface? and ns the normal? what is n_y ?

Thank you for taking a look at it. You are correct, n is the normal, n_y is the normal to the y-axis. I will have to verify u_tau, I believe it is the u component tangential to the surface, where its value may be zero at the surface, but its derivative is not necessarily zero.
I would recommend you remove the "diffusivity gradient product" routines, and write down the expression directly

Would you be able to provide a simple example of writing down an expression directly that involves a derivative with respect to the normal? I'm not sure of how to write it in the syntax required by MOOSE.

sure, use the chain rule
du/dn = du/dx dx/dn + du/dy dy/dn ...

then dx/dn is 1/n_x
